Title: Spaceflight Modulates the Expression of Key Oxidative Stress and Cell Cycle Related Genes in Heart
authors: Akhilesh Kumar, Candice G T Tahimic, Eduardo A C Almeida, Ruth K Globus
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Spaceﬂight causes cardiovascular changes due to microgravity-induced redistribution of body ﬂuids and musculoskeletal unloading. Cardiac deconditioning and atrophy on Earth are associated with altered Trp53 and oxidative stress-related pathways, but the effects of spaceﬂight on cardiac changes at the molecular level are less understood. We tested the hypothesis that spaceﬂight alters the expression of key genes related to stress response pathways, which may contribute to cardiovascular deconditioning during extended spaceﬂight. Spaceﬂight altered the expression of genes regulating redox balance, cell cycle and senescence in cardiac tissue of mice. Thus, spaceﬂight may contribute to cardiac dysfunction due to oxidative stress."

"Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) has a detrimental impact on human health on Earth and it is equally concerning in other environments such as space habitat due to microgravity, radiation and confinement, especially for long-distance space travel. Title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis
authors: Ilaria Giovannini, Thomas C Boothby, Michele Cesari, Bob Goldstein, Roberto Guidetti, Lorena Rebecchi
abstract_text:
El resumen del texto es el siguiente:

"Water unavailability is an abiotic stress causing unfavourable conditions for life. Nevertheless, some animals evolved anhydrobiosis, a strategy allowing for the reversible organism dehydration and suspension of metabolism as a direct response to habitat desiccation. In this study, the eutardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis was used to investigate the occurrence of reactive oxygen species (ROS) associated with the desiccation process. We observed that the production of ROS significantly increases as a function of time spent in anhydrobiosis and represents a direct demonstration of oxidative stress in tardigrades. Our study also confirms the involvement of various molecules, including aquaporins 3 and 10, during rehydration, highlighting the role of bioprotectants in desiccation tolerance."
title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis

authors: M Sung, J Li, AJ Spieker, J Spatz, R Ellman, VL Ferguson, TA Bateman, GD Rosen, M Bouxsein, SB Rutkove
abstract_text:

"Exposure to prolonged disuse or microgravity produces a variety of effects on skeletal muscle, including fiber atrophy, a reduction in maximal force, and reduced endurance. Novel approaches to reduce negative effects of spaceflight or prolonged bed rest/immobilization on musculoskeletal health are being sought. Electrical impedance myography (EIM) was used to assess muscle fiber atrophy and bone deterioration after spaceflight or hind limb unloading. Reductions in the multifrequency phase-slope parameter were observed for both the space flight and hind limb unloading cohorts compared to their respective controls. A continuación, se presenta el resumen del texto original:

"Cadiovascular progenitor cells (CPCs) cultivados en la Estación Espacial Internacional muestran propiedades desarrolladas y funcionales alteradas Jonathan Baio et al.

La misión espacial y la lesión en la Tierra alteran profundamente el corazón y sus componentes celulares. Se necesitan investigaciones adicionales para caracterizar y abordar los substratos moleculares de tales cambios. Se cultivaron células progenitoras cardiacas humanas neonatales y adultas en la Estación Espacial Internacional. Al regresar a la Tierra, medimos cambios en la expresión de microARN y de genes relacionados con la transdución mecánica, la cardiógenesi, la reproducción celular, la reparación del ADN y la señalización paracrina. Además, evaluamos la formación de tubos endoteliales, la reproducción celular y la capacidad de migración de las CPCs. Los cambios en la expresión de microARNs se predijeron que objetivaban la interacción con la matriz extracelular y la señalización del camino HIPPO en ambos CPCs neonatales y adultos. Los genes relacionados con la transdución mecánica (YAP1, RHOA) se descargaron, mientras que la expresión de genes citoesqueletales (VIM, NES, DES, LMNB2, LMNA) fue significativamente elevada en las CPCs neonatales. Los CPCs neonatales mostraron expresión aumentada de genes mesenodermales y disminución de la expresión de marcadores derivados mesodérmicos (TNNT2, VWF, y RUNX2), reducción en la preparación para formar tubos endoteliales y expresión elevada de Bmp y Tbx. Ambos CPCs neonatales y adultos mostraron expresión aumentada de genes de reparación del ADN y factores paracrinos, respaldada por mayor migración. Mientras que la navegación espacial afecta la organización citoesqueletal y la migración en CPCs neonatales y adultas, solo CPCs neonatales experimentaron expresión aumentada de marcadores de desarrollo temprano y potencial proliferativo elevado. Esfuerzos para recapitular los efectos de la navegación espacial en la Tierra al regular los procesos descritos aquí pueden ser una vía prometedora para reparación cardiaca."

Title: An Analysis of the Effects of Spaceflight and Vaccination on Antibody Repertoire Diversity
authors: Trisha A Rettig, John C Tan, Nina C Nishiyama, Stephen K Chapes, Michael J Pecaut
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

Ab repertoire diversity plays a critical role in the host's ability to fight pathogens. CDR3 is partially responsible for Ab–Ag binding and is a significant source of diversity in the repertoire. We analyzed the Ab repertoire diversity across multiple experiments examining the effects of spaceflight on the Ab repertoire after vaccination. Five datasets from four experiments were analyzed using rank-abundance curves and Shannon indices as measures of diversity. We discovered a trend toward lower diversity as a result of spaceflight but did not find the same decrease in our physiological model of microgravity in either the spleen or bone marrow. However, the bone marrow repertoire showed a reduction in diversity after vaccination. We also detected differences in Shannon indices between experiments and tissues.

Title: Effects of spaceflight aboard the International Space Station on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
authors: Xiaoman Hong, Anamika Ratri, Sungshin Y Choi, Joseph S Tash, April E Ronca, Joshua S Alwood, Lane K Christenson
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Ovarian steroids dramatically impact normal homeostatic and metabolic processes of most tissues within the body. Determining the effects of space ﬂight on the ovary and estrous cycle is, therefore, critical to our understanding of all space ﬂight experiments using female mice. Adult female mice ( n=10) were exposed to and sacriﬁced on-orbit after 37 days of space ﬂight in microgravity. The proportion of animals in each phase of the estrous cycle did not appreciably differ between baseline, vivarium, and ﬂight mice, while habitat control mice exhibited greater numbers in diestrus. Ovarian tissue steroid concentrations indicated no differences in estradiol across groups, while progesterone levels were lower in habitat and ﬂight compared to baseline females. These data support vaginal wall estrous cycle classiﬁcation of all female mice ﬂown in space, indicating females are likely undergoing ovarian cyclicity and may yet be fertile."

Impairment of the central nervous system (CNS) poses a significant health risk for astronauts during long-duration space missions. Our study integrated single-cell multiomics with spatial transcriptomics to elucidate the impact of space flight on the mouse brain in female mice. abstract_text:

"Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station.

The commercialization of space travel will soon lead to many more people living and working in unique built environments similar to the International Space Station, which is a specialized closed environment that contains its own indoor microbiome. We need a predictive approach for modeling microbial growth in these critical indoor spaces.

Here, we demonstrate that even short exposures to varying elevated relative humidity can facilitate rapid microbial growth and microbial community composition changes in dust from spacecraft. We modeled fungal growth in dust from the International Space Station using the time-of-wetness framework with activation and deac- tivation limited growth occurring at 85% and 100% relative humidity, respectively.

Our results demonstrate that moisture conditions can be used to develop and predict changes in fungal growth and composition onboard human-occupied spacecraft. This predictive model can be expanded upon to include other spacecraft environmental factors such as microgravity, elevated carbon dioxide conditions, and radiation exposure. authors: Zhong Chen, Seta Stanbouly, Nina C Nishiyama, Xin Chen, Michael D Delp, Hongyu Qiu, Xiao W Mao, Charles Wang
abstract_text:
El resumen del texto es:

"Astronauts exhiben una variedad de anormalidades clínicas en sus ojos durante largas duraciones de vuelo espacial. El objetivo de este estudio fue determinar si el vuelo espacial produce reprogramación epigenómica y transcriptómica en la retina o altera el reloj epigenético. Los ratones volaron durante 37 días en módulos de acuarios en la Estación Espacial Internacional; animales de control terrestres se mantuvieron bajo condiciones de vivienda similares. Las retinas de los ratones se aislaron y se determinó ambos el metiloma de ADN y el transcriptoma mediante secuenciación profunda. Encontramos que un gran número de genes estaban metilados de manera diferente con el vuelo espacial, mientras que había pocos genes con expresión diferencial en el nivel del transcriptoma. Varias vías biológicas involucradas en enfermedades de la retina, como la degeneración macular, fueron significativamente alteradas. Nuestros resultados indicaron que el vuelo espacial retardó el reloj epigenético retiniano. Este estudio demuestra que el vuelo espacial impacta la retina a nivel epigenómico y transcriptómico, y que tales cambios podrían estar involucrados en la etiología de enfermedades oculares relacionadas con los astronautas."

Title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence
authors: Kimberly L McArthur, Mridha Zakir, Asim Haque, J David Dickman
abstract_text:
El resumen del texto es:

"In all species studied, afferents from semicircular canals and otolith organs converge on central neurons in the brainstem. However, the spatial and temporal relationships between converging inputs and how these contribute to vestibular behaviors is not well understood. We used discrete rotational and translational motion stimuli to characterize canal- and otolith-driven response components of convergent non-eye movement (NEM) neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex of alert pigeons. Our findings suggest that convergent signals have similar gain and phase ranges, but exhibit greater spatial variability in their axes of preferred rotation. Neither response component alone nor a simple linear combination of these components was sufficient to predict actual net responses during combined canal-otolith stimulation."

abstract_text:
A continuación, te proporciono el resumen (abstract) limpio del texto:

"Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons

Here we demonstrate that human neural stem cells (NSCs) proliferate while in space and they express specific NSC markers after being in space. NSCs displayed both higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis than ground controls. These cells also kept their ability to become young neurons. Electrophysiological recordings of space NSC-derived neurons showed immature cell membrane properties, characterized by small capacitance and very high input resistance. Title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight
authors: Victoria Tran, Nicholas Carpo, Carlos Cepeda, Araceli Espinosa-Jeffrey
abstract_text:
El resumen está indicado en el siguiente texto:

"Intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) are some of the consequences of long-term space missions. Here we examined the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) after space ﬂight using time-lapse microscopy. We show that most OLPs divided more than ground control (GC) counterparts did. Nonetheless, a subpopulation of OLPs ﬂown to space presented a signiﬁcant increase in autophagic cell death. Examination of the proteomic proﬁle of the secretome of space ﬂown OLPs (SPC-OLPs) revealed that the stress protein heat shock protein-90 beta “HSP-90 ” was the 5thmost enriched (6.8 times) and the secreted protein acidic and rich in cysteine “SPARC” was the 7thmost enriched (5.2 times), with respect to ground control cells. SPARC induces endoplasmic reticulum stress, which leads to autophagy. Given the roles and importance of these two proteins in mammalian cells’ metabolism, their upregulation may hold the key to modulating cell proliferation and autophagy, in order to mitigate ICP and VIIP during and after space missions."

Title: Spaceflight Induces Specific Alterations in the Proteomes of Arabidopsis
authors: Robert J Ferl, Jin Koh, Fiona Denison, Anna-Lisa Paul
abstract_text:
Aquí se encuentra el resumen (abstract) del texto original:

"Life in spaceflight demonstrates remarkable acclimation processes within the specialized habitats of vehicles subjected to the myriad of unique environmental issues associated with orbital trajectories. To examine the response processes that occur in plants in space, leaves and roots from Arabidopsis seedlings from three GFP reporter lines that were grown from seed for 12 days on the International Space Station and preserved on orbit in RNAlater were returned to Earth and analyzed by using iTRAQ broad-scale proteomics procedures. Quantiﬁcation revealed 256 leaf proteins and 358 root proteins that showed statistically signiﬁcant differential abundance in the spaceﬂight samples compared to ground controls, with few proteins differentially regulated in common between leaves and roots. This indicates that there are measurable proteomics responses to spaceﬂight and that the responses are organ-speciﬁc."

Title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri
authors: Madeline M Vroom, Yaneli Rodriguez-Ocasio, Jonathan B Lynch, Edward G Ruby, Jamie S Foster
abstract_text:
El resumen o abstract del texto completo es el siguiente: 

Reduced gravity, o microgravity, puede tener un impacto pronunciado en la fisiología de los animales, pero los efectos en sus microbiomas asociados no están bien entendidos. Aquí, se examinó el impacto del microgravity modelado en la liberación de lipopolisacáridos (LPS) por el bacterium simbiótico Vibrio fischeri utilizando recipientes de alta relación de aspecto. Los LPS de V. fischeri están conocidos por inducir apoptosis de desarrollo dentro de sus tejidos simbióticos, lo que se acelera bajo condiciones de microgravity modelado. Se encontró que la exposición a microgravity modelado incrementa la cantidad de LPS liberada por el simbionte bacteriano in vitro. Estudios anteriores han correlacionado la producción de vesículas de membrana exterior (OMV) con la motilidad flagelar. Se observó que mutantes de V. fischeri defectuosos en la producción y rotación de sus flagelos muestran disminuciones significativas en la liberación de LPS en todos los tratamientos, pero los niveles de LPS son más altos bajo microgravity modelado a pesar de la pérdida de motilidad. Este resultado sugiere que, como sus huéspedes animales, la fisiología de los microbios simbióticos se puede alterar bajo condiciones de microgravity, lo que puede tener implicaciones importantes para la salud del huésped durante el vuelo espacial.
title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri

Title: Preservation of Multiple Mammalian Tissues to Maximize Science Return from Ground Based and Spaceflight Experiments
authors: Sungshin Choi, Hami E Ray, San-Huei Lai, Joshua S Alwood, Ruth K Globus
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Background: Even with recent scientific advancements, challenges posed by limited resources and capabilities at the time of sample dissection continue to limit the collection of high quality tissues from experiments that can be conducted only infrequently and at high cost, such as in space.

Objectives: The goals of this study were to optimize methods for both sample recovery and science return from rodent experiments, with possible relevance to both ground-based and space-flight studies.

Methods: Tissues of C57Bl/6J mice were dissected and preserved at various time points post-euthanasia and stored at -80°C for up to 11 months. RNA quantity and quality was assessed by measuring RNA Integrity Number (RIN) values using an Agilent Bioanalyzer.

Results: Fresh tissues were collected up to one hour post-euthanasia, and stored up to 11 months at -80°C, with minimal adverse effects on the RNA quality of either livers or RNA-later-preserved spleens."

Title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight
authors: Vidya Manian, Jairo Orozco-Sandoval, Victor Diaz-Martinez, Heeralal Janwa, Carlos Agrinsoni
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

Skeletal muscle atrophy es una condición común en la vejez, el diabetes y las largas duraciones de la misión de espacio debido a la microgravedad. Este artículo investiga la predicción de la red de genes y enfermedades y la red de medicamentos para enfermedades a través de algoritmos de predictión de enlaces para seleccionar medicamentos para reutilizar el tratamiento de la atrofia muscular. Se detectaron genes objetivo clave que causan la atrofia muscular en el músculo extensor digitorum longus de la mano izquierda y derecha, muslo, bíceps, y los músculos sóleo izquierdo y derecho. Se utilizó análisis de redes teóricas para detectar genes objetivo clave a partir de los conjuntos de datos transcriptómicos recopilados de ratones lanzados en vuelo espacial disponibles por GeneLab. Identificamos los principales reguladores de genes de atrofia muscular mediante la correlación de Pearson y el método de manto de Markov Bayesiano. Se construyó un gráfico de conocimiento de enfermedad y medicina a través del motor de precisión de medicina escalable. Se calcularon inserciones de nodos, medidas de caminata aleatoria desde las redes. Se entrenaron redes convolucionales de gráficos, redes neuronales de gráficos, bosques aleatorios y métodos de aumento de gradientes usando las inserciones de nodos y características de redes para predecir enlaces y clasificar a los genes más relevantes para la enfermedad de atrofia muscular. Los medicamentos se seleccionaron y se construyó un gráfico de conocimiento de enfermedad y medicina. Se aplicaron métodos de prediccion de enlaces a las redes de medicamentos para enfermedades para identificar los medicamentos con un alto nivel de priorización para el tratamiento terapéutico de la atrofia muscular. La red convolutiva de gráficos funciona mejor en la prediccion de enlaces en función de las curvas de característica recetora y la precisión de predicción. Los genes clave involucrados en la atrofia muscular se asocian con enfermedades metabolicas y neurodegenerativas. Los medicamentos seleccionados para reutilizar usando el método de red convolutiva de gráficos fueron nutrientes, esteroides de corticosteroides antiinflamatorios, medicamentos y otros relacionados con la insulina.
title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight

abstract_text:

La fuerza de la gravedad ha moldeado la vida en la Tierra y impacta la expresión de genes y la morfogénesis durante el desarrollo temprano. Sin embargo, la desuso en la Tierra o durante la misión espacial reduce la carga mecánica normal de los organismos, resultando en funciones alteradas de las células y los tejidos. En este estudio, se investigó cómo una pulse de 60 minutos de 50 g de gravedad superfluir (HG) / 5 kPa de presión hidrostática influye en la regulación de la transcriptomía en el cuerpo embrionario (EB) modelo a través de una secuenciación de ARN de célula única. El resultados indican que HG indujo upregulación de genes de auto renovación y angiogénesis en células madre embrionarias (ESCs), mientras que en EB, la carga mecánica resultó en la upregulación de vías de ontología del gen para el desarrollo multicelular, la transducción de señales mecánicas y la reparación del daño del ADN. Los resultados sugieren que la regulación del mantenimiento de las células madre y el desarrollo del EB pueden estar influenciados por el mecanotransducción y que las células comprometidas con un programa de diferenciación están más sensibles a los cambios inducidos por la gravedad en la transcriptoma.

authors: Joshua P Vandenbrink, John Z Kiss, Raul Herranz, F Javier Medina
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Tropisms are growth-mediated plant movements that help plants to respond to changes in environmental stimuli. The plant response to gravity (gravitropism) and the response to unidirectional light (phototropism) have long been shown to be interconnected growth phenomena. We discuss the similarities in these two processes, as well as the known molecular mechanisms behind the tropistic responses. Microgravity and light irradiation produce important effects on meristematic cells, affecting cell cycle regulation, ribosome biogenesis, and phytohormone actions. Upcoming experiments on the International Space Station will clarify some of the mechanisms and molecular players of the plant responses to these environmental signals involved in tropisms and the cell cycle."

Title: Comparative transcriptomics indicate changes in cell wall organization and stress response in seedlings during spaceflight
authors: Christina M Johnson, Aswati Subramanian, Sivakumar Pattathil, Melanie J Correll, John Z Kiss
abstract_text:
Aquí está el resumen (abstract) extraído del texto:

"Plants will play an important role in the future of space exploration as part of bioregenerative life support. Thus, it is important to understand the effects of microgravity and spaceflight on gene expression in plant development. We analyzed the transcriptome of Arabidopsis thaliana using the Biological Research in Canisters (BRIC) hardware during Space Shuttle mission STS-131. Our results showed expression changes in genes involved in hypoxia and heat shock responses, DNA repair, and cell wall structure between spaceflight samples compared to the ground controls. We also found differences in cell wall components between ground control and spaceflight-grown plants. A common theme from our studies was the downregulation of water stress response genes in spaceflight, as well as differential regulation of genes associated with cell wall remodeling and stress responses between spaceflight-grown and ground control plants."

authors: John Z Kiss, Chris Wolverton, Sarah E Wyatt, Karl H Hasenstein, Jack JWA van Loon
abstract_text:
Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development

Plants have evolved under the influence of Earth’s gravity, a force of “1 g. ” This ubiquitous force affects plant growth, development, and morphology at all levels, from the molecular to the whole plant. Understanding gravitational effects requires changing the magnitude of this force. One method of eliminating gravity’s influence is to enter into a free-fall orbit around the planet, thereby achieving a balance between centripetal force of gravity and the centrifugal force of the moving object. This balance is often mistakenly referred to as microgravity, but is best described as weightlessness. 

We provide a review of the strengths and weaknesses of analogs for the study of plant growth and development compared to spaceflight experiments, and consider reduced or partial gravity effects via spaceflight and analog methods. While these analogs are useful, the fidelity of the results relative to spaceflight depends on biological parameters and environmental conditions that cannot be simulated in ground-based studies. 

Keywords: Arabidopsis, clinostat, plant growth, simulated microgravity, random positioning machine, reduced gravity, spaceflight experiments.
title: Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development

Title: Detection of Genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. Responding to DNA Damage from Radiation and Other Stressors in Spaceflight
authors: Vidya Manian, Jairo Orozco-Sandoval, Victor Diaz-Martinez
abstract_text: Abstract: Ionizing radiation present in extraterrestrial environment is an important factor that affects plants grown in spaceﬂight. Pearson correlation-based gene regulatory network inferencing from transcriptional responses of the plant Arabidopsis thaliana L. grown in real and simulated spaceﬂight conditions acquired by GeneLab, followed by topological and spectral analysis of the networks is performed. Gene regulatory subnetworks are extracted for DNA damage response processes. Analysis of radiation-induced ATR/ATM protein–protein interactions in Arabidopsis reveals interaction proﬁle similarities under low radiation doses suggesting novel mechanisms of DNA damage response involving non-radiation-induced genes regulating other stress responses in spaceﬂight. The Jaccard similarity index shows that the genes AT2G31320, AT4G21070, AT2G46610, and AT3G27060 perform similar functions under low doses of radiation. The incremental association Markov blanket method reveals non-radiation-induced genes linking DNA damage response to root growth and plant development. Eighteen radiation-induced genes and sixteen non-radiation-induced gene players have been identiﬁed from the ATR/ATM protein interaction complexes involved in heat, salt, water, osmotic stress responses, and plant organogenesis. Network analysis and logistic regression ranking detected AT3G27060, AT1G07500, AT5G66140, and AT3G21280 as key gene players involved in DNA repair processes. High atomic weight, high energy, and gamma photon radiation result in higher intensity of DNA damage response in the plant resulting in elevated values for several network measures such as spectral gap and girth. Nineteen ﬂavonoid and carotenoid pigment activations involved in pigment biosynthesis processes are identiﬁed in low radiation dose total light spaceﬂight environment but are not found to have signiﬁcant regulations under very high radiation dose environment.
title: Detection of Genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. Responding to DNA Damage from Radiation and Other Stressors in Spaceflight

abstract_text:
A continuación, te presento el resumen (abstract) del texto:

"El objetivo de la misión Inspiración 4 (I4), la primera misión orbital de vuelo no tripulado, fue investigar los efectos fisiológicos del vuelo espacial de corta duración a través de un enfoque multiómico. A pesar de los avances, quedan muchos aspectos por aprender sobre la adaptación humana a los desafíos únicos del vuelo espacial, incluyendo la microgravedad, las perturbaciones del sistema inmunológico y la exposición a la radiación. Nuestros resultados muestran que la longitud de los telómeros se alarga durante el vuelo espacial y se reduce posteriormente. Además, la estabilidad genómica y las adaptaciones inmunes fueron medidas a través de secuenciación de DNA y análisis bioinformático, lo que sugiere que el cuerpo humano tiene la capacidad de adaptarse a los desafíos del vuelo espacial, aunque es necesario investigar más sobre este tema."

abstract_text:
El resumen del texto es:

"La creciente accesibilidad de la viaje espacial comercial y privada requiere una profunda comprensión de su impacto en la salud humana. El NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) proporciona acceso transparente y FAIR a estudios biológicos, incluyendo la mision del SpaceX Inspiration4, que reunió grandes cantidades de datos desde astronautas civiles. Estos datos permiten mediciones multi-modales, de largo plazo, y cubren la brecha entre estudios humanos y de organismos modelo. Con la ayuda de comunidades de datos de la NASA, la inteligencia artificial y la aprendizaje automático pueden extraer valiosas conclusiones, guiando la planeación futura de misiones y la mitigación de riesgos para la salud. Este artículo presentsa una guía concisa para acceder y analizar los datos de I4 en el OSDR, incluyendo el acceso programático a través de GLOpenAPI, estableciendo un precedente para monitorear la salud después de la misión en agencias espaciales".

"Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) y biobanco internacional de astronautas. El espacio induce cambios moleculares, celulares y fisiológicos en los astronautas y plantea numerosos desafíos biomédicos para el cuerpo humano, que se vuelven cada vez más relevantes a medida que más personas viajan al espacio. Presentamos la plataforma SOMA, una base de datos y repositorio de muestras integrada para investigaciones de perfiles clínicos, celulares y multiómicas de diferentes misiones, incluyendo la NASA Twins Study, JAXA CFE estudio y SpaceX Inspiration4 crew. El acceso al espacio aumenta exponencialmente desde 2019, y se está construyendo un espacio espacial, colonias en la luna, colonias en Marte y otras establecimientos permanentes en el espacio."

Title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis
authors: Nicole M Gibbs, Shih‐Heng Su, Samuel Lopez‐Nieves, Stéphane Mann, Claude Alban, Hiroshi A Maeda, Patrick H Masson
abstract_text:
RESUMEN
Cadaverina, una poliamina, ha estado relacionada con la modificación de la arquitectura de crecimiento de raíces y la respuesta a estrés ambiental en plantas. Sin embargo, los mecanismos moleculares que gobiernan la regulación del crecimiento de raíces por cadaverina están poco explorados. Se aisló un mutante, cadaverina hiper sensible 3 (cdh3), que resultó en una sensibilidad aumentada al crecimiento de raíces de cadaverina, pero no a otras poliaminas. Esta mutación afecta la gene biotin biosynthesis BIO3-BIO1. El suministro exógeno de biotina y un intermediario de la vía downstream de BIO1, 7,8-diaminopelargónico ácido, suprimió este fenotipo de sensibilidad a cadaverina. Un ensayo de actividad enzimática in vitro mostró que cadaverina inhibe la actividad de BIO3-BIO1. Además, los plántulas tratadas con cadaverina mostraron una reducción de la biotinilación de la proteína de transportador de biotina 1 del complejo de carboxilasa de acetil coenzima A, lo que resultó en una disminución de la acumulación de triacilglicéridos. En conjunto, estos resultados revelan un papel inesperado de la cadaverina en la regulación de la síntesis de biotina, que lleva a la modulación del crecimiento de raíces primario de plantas.
title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis

Title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues
authors: Mackenzie L Hagan, Vanshika Balayan, Meghan E McGee-Lawrence
abstract_text:
Aquí te presento el resumen extraído del texto:

"Mammalian cells emplean una variedad de mecanismos biológicos para detectar y responder a la carga mecánica en su entorno. La formación de disruptions del membrana plasmática (PMD) fomenta un flujo molecular a través de membranas celulares que promueve la adaptación tisular. La reparación de PMD a través de una actividad orquestada de maquinaria molecular es crucial para la supervivencia celular, y la tasa de reparación de PMD puede afectar la señalización celular downstream. Las observaciones de PMD han influido en el comportamiento mecánico de células epiteliales de piel, alveolos, intestino, células de aorta endoteliales, queratocitos corneales y células epiteliales, mitocitos musculares cardíacos y esqueléticos, neuronas y recientemente, células de hueso incluyendo osteoblastos, células del ligamento periodontal y osteocitos.

La intención de esta revisión es describir los procesos de formación y reparación de PMD en estas tejidos sensibles a la carga mecánica, con un énfasis especial en comparar y contrastar mecanismos de reparación y señalización downstream para comprender mejor el papel de PMD en la bioingeniería mecánica ósea.

Las implicaciones de los mecanismos relacionados con PMD para la enfermedad y las aplicaciones terapéuticas potenciales también se exploran."
title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues

Title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation
authors: Camilla Urbaniak, Hernan Lorenzi, James Thissen, Crystal Jaing, Brian Crucian, Clarence Sams, Duane Pierson, Kasthuri Venkateswaran, Satish Mehta
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

Background: Spaceflight impacts astronauts in many ways but little is known on how spaceflight affects the salivary microbiome and the consequences of these changes on astronaut health, such as viral reactivation.

Results: Streptococcus was the most abundant organism in the saliva, making up 8% of the total organisms detected, and their diversity decreased during spaceflight. Other organisms that had statistically significant changes were Proteobacteria and Fusobacteria which increased during flight and Actinobacteria which decreased during flight.

Conclusions: This is the first study to look at how the salivary microbiome changes as a result of spaceflight and the search for bacterial biomarkers for viral reactivation. Further studies examining the role of specific organisms that were shown to be correlative and predictive in viral reactivation, a serious problem in astronauts during spaceflight, could lead to mitigation strategies to help prevent disease during both short and long duration space missions.
title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation

"The SpaceX Inspiration4 mission provided a unique opportunity to study the impact of space flight on the human body. We collected and processed 2,911 sample aliquots from four crew members longitudinally before, during, and after space flight, spanning 289 days. Metabolomic Analysis of Aspergillus niger Isolated From the International Space Station Reveals Enhanced Production Levels of the Antioxidant Pyranonigrin A.

La investigación describe la producción de metabolitos secundarios en Aspergillus niger JSC-093350089, aislado de la Estación Espacial Internacional (ISS), en comparación con la cepa establecida ATCC 1015. Se encontró un aumento en la producción de naftho-g-piros y metabolitos secundarios terapéuticamente relevantes, incluyendo bicoumanigrin A, aurasperones A y B, y el antioxidante pyranonigrin A. Title: Spaceflight Activates Autophagy Programs and the Proteasome in Mouse Liver
authors: Elizabeth A Blaber, Michael J Pecaut, Karen R Jonscher
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Increased oxidative stress is an unavoidable consequence of exposure to the space environment. Our previous studies showed that mice exposed to space for 13.5 days had decreased glutathione levels, suggesting impairments in oxidative defense. Here we performed unbiased, unsupervised and integrated multi-‘omic analyses of metabolomic and transcriptomic datasets from mice flown aboard the Space Shuttle Atlantis. We found increased enrichment of aminoacyl-tRNA biosynthesis and purine metabolic pathways, concomitant with enrichment of genes associated with autophagy and the ubiquitin-proteasome. When taken together with a downregulation in nuclear factor (erythroid-derived 2)-like 2-mediated signaling, our analyses suggest that decreased hepatic oxidative defense may lead to aberrant tRNA post-translational processing, induction of degradation programs and senescence-associated mitochondrial dysfunction in response to the spaceflight environment."
title: Spaceflight Activates Autophagy Programs and the Proteasome in Mouse Liver

abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Bioinformatics approaches have proven useful in understanding biological responses to spaceﬂight. Spaceﬂight experiments remain resource intensive and rare. authors: Megan Hupka, Raj Kedia, Rylee Schauer, Brooke Shepard, María Granados-Presa, Mark Vande Hei, Pamela Flores, Luis Zea
abstract_text:
El resumen o abstract del texto es:

"Abstract: Fungi bioﬁlms have been found growing on spacecraft surfaces such as windows, piping, cables, etc. The contamination of these surfaces with fungi, although undesirable, is highly difﬁcult to avoid. While several bioﬁlm forming species, including Penicillium rubens, have been identiﬁed in spacecraft, the effect of microgravity on fungal bioﬁlm formation is unknown. This study sent seven material surfaces (Stainless Steel 316, Aluminum Alloy, Titanium Alloy, Carbon Fiber, Quartz, Silicone, and Nanograss) inoculated with spores of P. rubens to the International Space Station and allowed bioﬁlms to form for 10, 15, and 20 days to understand the effects of microgravity on bioﬁlm morphology and growth. In general, microgravity did not induce changes in the shape of bioﬁlms, nor did it affect growth in terms of biomass, thickness, and surface area coverage. However, microgravity increased or decreased bioﬁlm formation in some cases, and this was incubation-time- and material-dependent. Nanograss was the material with signiﬁcantly less bioﬁlm formation, both in microgravity and on Earth, and it could potentially be interfering with hyphal adhesion and/or spore germination."

"Despite a wealth of data on the effects of spaceflight on tendons and bones, little is known about its effects on the interfacial tissue between these two structures, the enthesis. Mice were sent to space on three separate missions to determine how spaceflight affects the composition, structure, mechanics, and gene expression of the humerus-supraspinatus and calcaneus-Achilles entheses. Title: Leptin and environmental temperature as determinants of bone marrow adiposity in female mice
authors: Russell T Turner, Kira L Nesser, Kenneth A Philbrick, Carmen P Wong, Dawn A Olson, Adam J Branscum, Urszula T Iwaniec
abstract_text:
Aquí está el resumen (abstract) extraído del texto:

"Increased housing temperature and increased leptin have independent but opposing effects on bone marrow adiposity (BMAT) in mice. At thermoneutral temperature (32°C), female mice have higher BMAT levels, abdominal white adipose tissue (WAT) mass, and serum leptin. We found that leptin supplementation reduced BMAT and increased bone formation in distal femur metaphysis, changes not replicated by pair-feeding. In contrast, BMAT increased in both wild type and leptin-deficient ob/ob mice housed at 32°C, but infusion of leptin into ob/ob mice attenuated the increase in BMAT. These findings suggest that increased leptin and temperature have independent but opposing effects on BMAT in mice."
title: Leptin and environmental temperature as determinants of bone marrow adiposity in female mice

Title: Small changes in thermoregulation influence cancellous bone turnover balance in distal femur metaphysis in growing female mice
authors: Lara H Sattgast, Carmen P Wong, Adam J Branscum, Dawn A Olson, Allan M Aguirre-Burk, Urszula T Iwaniec, Russell T Turner
abstract_text:
ABSTRACT 

Mice are typically housed at temperatures well below their thermoneutral zone. When individually housed at room temperature (~22 •C) mice experience cold stress which results in cancellous bone loss and has the potential to alter the skeletal response to treatment. It is not clear if there is a threshold temperature for cold stress-induced bone loss. It is also not clear if alternative strategies for attenuating cold stress, such as group housing, influence bone accrual and turnover. 

This study aimed to determine how small differences in temperature (4 •C) or heat loss (individual versus group housing with nestlets) influence bone in growing female C57BL/6 J mice. The study found that mice single housed at room temperature had increased body weight and femur size, but dramatically decreased cancellous bone volume fraction in distal femur metaphysis. The cancellous bone loss was attenuated but not prevented in mice individually housed at 26 •C or group housed at 22 •C. In conclusion, by impacting thermogenesis or heat loss, modest differences in housing conditions could influence experimental results.
title: Small changes in thermoregulation influence cancellous bone turnover balance in distal femur metaphysis in growing female mice

authors: Camilla Urbaniak, Tristan Grams, Christopher E Mason, Kasthuri Venkateswaran
abstract_text:
Aquí está el resumen (abstract) extraído del texto:

"Bacteria son capaces de adaptarse y sobrevivir en entornos hostiles y cambiantes a través de varios mecanismos, con uno de ellos siendo la transferencia horizontal de genes (TGH). Este proceso es uno de los principales responsables de la propagación de la resistencia antimicrobiana (RAM) dentro de las comunidades bacterianas y podría suponer una amenaza significativa para la salud de los astronautas si éstos tuvieran una enfermedad, especialmente en misiones espaciales de larga duración. Para entender mejor el grado de actividad de TGH que podría ocurrir en el espacio, se cultivó a nivel biosafetad 2, a bacterias donadoras y receptoras bajo gravedad simulada (SMG) en la Tierra, con controles 1G concomitantes. Se siguieron dos genes de RAM, blaOXA-500 y ISAba1, de la bacteria donadora Acinetobacter pittii, en cuatro cepas receptoras de Staphylococcus aureus (que no habían albergado esos genes). Todas las cuatro cepas de S. aureus que se co-cultivaron con A. pittii bajo SMG tenían un número significativamente más alto de aislados que eran ahora blaOXA-500 y ISAba1 positivos en comparación con el crecimiento a 1G. La adquisición de estos genes por el receptor indujo un cambio fenotípico, ya que estos aislados eran ahora resistentes a oxacilina, a la que anteriormente eran susceptibles. Esto es un estudio novel, presentando, por primera vez, un aumento de la actividad de TGH bajo SMG y el potencial impacto del entorno espacial en la promoción de un mayor despliegue de genes dentro de las comunidades bacterianas."

"Locomotion of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans is a key observable used in investigations ranging from behavior to neuroscience to aging. We present a quantitative analysis of how the nematode reorients itself in 3D media, identifying a unique behavioral state of C. elegans — a roll maneuver — which is an essential component of 3D locomotion in burrowing and swimming. Title: Swim exercise in Caenorhabditis elegans extends neuromuscular and gut healthspan, enhances learning ability, and protects against neurodegeneration
authors: Ricardo Laranjeiro, Girish Harinath, Jennifer E Hewitt, Jessica H Hartman, Mary Anne Royal, Joel N Meyer, Siva A Vanapalli, Monica Driscoll
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Regular physical exercise is the most efficient and accessible intervention known to promote healthy aging in humans. The molecular and cellular mechanisms that mediate system-wide exercise benefits, however, remain poorly understood. We document optimization of a long-term swim exercise protocol for Caenorhabditis elegans and demonstrate its benefits to diverse aging tissues, even if exercise occurs only during a restricted phase of adulthood. Swim exercise training enhances whole-animal health parameters, increases functional healthspan of the pharynx and intestine, and enhances nervous system health by increasing learning ability and protecting against neurodegeneration. Our data reveal the broad impact of swim exercise in promoting extended healthspan of multiple C. elegans tissues, underscore the potency of early exercise experience to influence long-term health, and establish the foundation for exploiting the powerful advantages of this genetic model for the dissection of the exercise-dependent molecular circuitry that confers system-wide health benefits to aging adults."

authors: Ricardo Laranjeiro, Girish Harinath, Amelia K Pollard, Christopher J Gaffney, Colleen S Deane, Siva A Vanapalli, Timothy Etheridge, Nathaniel J Szewczyk, Monica Driscoll
abstract_text:
A continuación te presento el resumen (abstract) extraído del texto del paper:

Extended space travel is a goal of government space agencies and private companies. However, spaceﬂight poses risks to human health, and the effects on the nervous system have to be better characterized. Here, we exploited the unique experimental advantages of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to explore how spaceﬂight affects adult neurons in vivo . We found that animals that lived 5 days of adulthood on the International Space Station exhibited hyper-branching in PVD and touch receptor neurons. We also found that, in the presence of a neuronal proteotoxic stress, spaceﬂight promotes a remarkable accumulation of neuronal-derived waste in the surrounding tissues, suggesting an impaired transcellular degradation of debris released from neurons. Our data reveal that spaceﬂight can significantly affect adult neuronal morphology and clearance of neuronal trash, highlighting the need to carefully assess the risks of long-duration spaceﬂight on the nervous system and to develop adequate countermeasures for safe space exploration.

Title: Spaceflight Induces Strength Decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
authors: Purushottam Soni, Hunter Edwards, Taslim Anupom, Mizanur Rahman, Leila Lesanpezeshki, Jerzy Blawzdziewicz, Henry Cope, Nima Gharahdaghi, Daniel Scott, Li Shean Toh, Philip M Williams, Timothy Etheridge, Nathaniel Szewczyk, Craig R G Willis, Siva A Vanapalli
abstract_text:
El resumen (abstract) del texto es:

"Abstract: Background: Understanding and countering the well-established negative health consequences of spaceﬂight remains a primary challenge preventing safe deep space exploration. Targeted/personalized therapeutics are at the forefront of space medicine strategies, and cross-species molecular signatures now define the ‘typical’ spaceﬂight response. However, a lack of direct genotype– phenotype associations currently limits the robustness and, therefore, the therapeutic utility of putative mechanisms underpinning pathological changes in ﬂight. Methods: We employed the worm Caenorhabditis elegans as a validated model of space biology, combined with ‘NemaFlex-S’ microﬂuidic devices for assessing animal strength production as one of the most reproducible physiological responses to spaceﬂight. Wild-type and dys-1 (BZ33) strains (a Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) model for comparing predisposed muscle weak animals) were cultured on the International Space Station in chemically defined media before loading second-generation gravid adults into NemaFlex-S devices to assess individual animal strength. These same cultures were then frozen on orbit before returning to Earth for next-generation sequencing transcriptomic analysis. Results: Neuromuscular strength was lower in ﬂight versus ground controls (16.6% decline, p< 0.05), with no difference between wild-type and dys-1 strains. Our results implicate spaceﬂight in strength decline in an invertebrate model, which may inform novel therapeutic strategies to combat muscle weakness in space-faring populations."

In the wild, C. elegans are emersed in environments teeming with a veritable menagerie of microorganisms. The C. elegans cuticular surface serves as a barrier and first point of contact with their microbial environments. In this study, we identify microbes from C. elegans natural habitats that associate with its cuticle, constituting a simple “skin microbiome. ” We show that this skin microbiome promotes host cuticle integrity in harsh environments. Together, we identify a skin microbiome for the well-studied nematode model and propose its value in conferring host fitness advantages in naturalized contexts.

abstract_text: Nineteen strains de la orden Lactobacillales se aislaron de la Estación Espacial Internacional y el vehículo de abastecimiento comercial, y se generaron secuencias de genomes completas (WGS). Miembros del género Enterococcus poseen características de patogenicidad en humanos como resistencia a antibióticos, lo que plantea preocupaciones de salud para las personas de la Tierra y los astronautas residentes en la Estación Espacial Internacional (ISS). Title: Genomic analysis reveals the presence of emerging pathogenic Klebsiella lineages aboard the International Space Station

Abstract:
Klebsiella species, such as Klebsiella pneumoniae, Klebsiella aerogenes, and Klebsiella quasipneumoniae, are opportunistic pathogens that cause infections in humans. Hypervirulent Klebsiella pneumoniae (hvKP) has gained attention due to its global dissemination, invasive infections in community settings among immunocompetent individuals, and escalating antibiotic resistance levels. This study presents the first comprehensive phenotypic and genotypic analysis of Klebsiella isolates from the International Space Station (ISS), revealing emerging pathogenic lineages with potential implications for human health. The genomes of K. pneumoniae, K. aerogenes, and K. quasipneumoniae offered insights into antimicrobial resistance, virulence, thermotolerance, disinfectant resistance, and mobile genetic elements. Title: Spatial regulation of a common precursor from two distinct genes generates metabolite diversity
authors: Chun-Jun Guo, Wei-Wen Sun, Kenneth S Bruno, Berl R Oakley, Nancy P Keller, Clay C C Wang
abstract_text:
Spatial regulation of a common precursor from two distinct genes generates metabolite diversity.

Heterologous expression of all the A. terreus NRPS-like genes showed that two NRPS-like proteins, encoded by atmelA and apvA, release the same natural product, aspulvinone E. In hyphae this compound is converted to aspulvinones whereas in conidia it is converted to melanin. The genes are expressed in different tissues and this spatial control is probably regulated by their own specific promoters. Comparative genomics indicates that atmelA and apvA might share a same ancestral gene and the gene apvA is located in a highly conserved region in Aspergillus species that contains genes coding for life-essential proteins. Our data reveal the first case in secondary metabolite biosynthesis in which the tissue-specific production of a single compound directs it into two separate pathways, producing distinct compounds with different functions. Our data also reveal that a single trans-prenyltransferase, AbpB, prenylates two substrates, aspulvinones and butyrolactones, revealing that genes outside of contiguous secondary metabolism gene clusters can modify more than one compound thereby expanding metabolite diversity.
title: Spatial regulation of a common precursor from two distinct genes generates metabolite diversity

Immune cells incubated in RWVs exhibit several features of immunosuppression including impaired leukocyte proliferation, cytokine responses, and antibody production. These pathways are crucial defense mechanisms that protect the cell from toxins, pathogens, and radiation. We investigated the synergistic effects of isoproterenol (a sympathomimetic drug), radiation, and microgravity in nonstimulated immune cells. Mixed model regression analyses showed signiﬁcant synergistic effects on the expression of the 2-adrenergic receptor gene (ADRB2). Radiation alone increased ADRB2 expression, and cells incubated in microgravity had more DNA strand breaks than cells incubated in normal gravity. We observed radiation-induced cytokine production only in microgravity. Prior treatment with isoproterenol clearly prevents most of the microgravity-mediated effects. RWVs may be a useful tool to provide insight into novel regulatory pathways, providing beneﬁt not only to astronauts but also to patients suffering from immune disorders or undergoing radiotherapy."

Title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station.
authors: Nicholas Nastasi, Ashleigh Bope, Marit E Meyer, John M Horack, Karen C Dannemiller
abstract_text:
Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station.

The commercialization of space travel will soon lead to many more people living and working in unique built environments similar to the International Space Station, which is a specialized closed environment that contains its own indoor microbiome. Unintended microbial growth can occur in these environments as in buildings on Earth from elevated moisture, such as from a temporary ventilation system failure. This growth can drive negative health outcomes and degrade building materials. We need a predictive approach for modeling microbial growth in these critical indoor spaces.

We demonstrate that even short exposures to varying elevated relative humidity can facilitate rapid microbial growth and microbial community composition changes in dust from spacecraft. Our results show that moisture conditions can be used to develop and predict changes in fungal growth and composition onboard human-occupied spacecraft. This predictive model can be expanded upon to include other spacecraft environmental factors such as microgravity, elevated carbon dioxide conditions, and radiation exposure. Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft can help better protect astronaut health, fortify spacecraft integrity, and promote planetary protection as human activity increases in low-Earth orbit, the moon, Mars, and beyond.
title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
